posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: We currently have a rev through bore encoder which is wired into a Candi. The Candi is then set as a remote encoder source for our pivot motor. Sometimes when we turn on the robot the value reports 1+ when it’s supposed to be between 0 and 1. This value goes back to normal when we power cycle but why is this an issue. How do we fix this?

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
I think this is normal, we are seeing this as well. I haven’t fully thought through why, but it could have to do with the offset. If you have an offset of 0.5 and the encoder’s value is 0.75 when it boots up, the absolute position would be 1.25.

If this is causing problems for you, share what you’re running into and we can help you solve it. CTRE has a few features that might help, or you might have to use modulus on the angle to get it into the range you expect.

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: @gdefender This is definitely causing problems for us. Because if it stays at above 1 when the end effector moves to its points it would sever the wires that are attaches to the end effector. How would we solve this? What are the ctre tools that can help us with this? Also how would we use modulus to help with this issue

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
I’m going to take a guess here, you have an arm that can rotate less than 360 degrees. You have a REV Through Bore encoder, wired using the WHITE wire, so it’s an absolute encoder. You want to set soft limits near your hard stops (where the arm is physically unable to move), and you want to use position or Motion Magic control to move the arm to a position. You have a TalonFX motor controller (Falcon 500, Kraken, or FXS) to move the arm.

With this setup, you would:

configure the CANdi’s AbsoluteSensorDiscontinuityPoint to be in the center of your hard stops.

DO NOT enable ClosedLoopGeneral.ContinuousWrap in the motor controller’s config.

set the offset so the arm straight out is zero.

set the sensor and motor controller inverts so upward from zero is positive.

optionally, but highly recommended, configure the kG feedforward gain and configure GravityType to Arm_Cosine

assuming you’re using remote sensor type (you don’t have Phoenix Pro), use the withLimitForwardMotion and withLimitReverseMotion feature of the motor controller’s control request to enforce soft limits, just in case.

With this setup, the position will stay within one rotation in the range defined by the discontinuity point, so you can command it to go to a location.

NOTE: If the arm is capable of moving 360-degrees (has no hard stop limiting it from going more than one rotation), but it cannot without severing wires, there is no 100% safe way to avoid this programmatically. You can control what the program does, but you can’t control what happens when the robot is off or disabled, and you only get absolute position within one rotation. There’s no programmatic way to know if the arm was rotated over 360-degrees when the robot was powered off.

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: We have an arm that can go almost 360 but we have on hard-stop preventing it from going -above 360 forward and backward. We will probably just use modulus. Currently our discontinuity point is 1 which helps us return values from 0 - 1. And our 0 offset is vertical down. Thank you for opening our minds to the modulus operator we most likely have an if-statement that says the position to use  % 1 if the value is above 1. We have the Phoenix pro license what type of encoder class would you suggest using instead of remote? Is there a better one in this case

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: Would it be a good idea to use modulus if statement described in the message above in combination with the SyncEncoder class. Or would that mess up the data that is provided through this class. Would It be a good idea to use just the syncEncoder class

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Prince:

We have the Phoenix pro license what type of encoder class would you suggest using instead of remote?

With Phoenix Pro, you can use Synced or Fused mode. However, if you’re going to try to use modulus and the motor controller’s closed-loop control, you probably need to enable continuous wrap so you can command it to a position within one rotation.

Prince:

have an if-statement that says the position to use % 1 if the value is above 1

An easy way to handle it whether it’s positive or negative is ((rotations % 1.0) + 1.0) % 1.0

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: Do you think both modulus and sync is required or do you think sync will be enough

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked:
I don’t think continuous wrap would work for us because we can’t go above 360 we have a hardstop to prevent us from doing that because we don’t want to rip off our end effector wires

gdefender:

However, if you’re going to try to use modulus and the motor controller’s closed-loop control, you probably need to enable continuous wrap so you can command it to a position within one rotation.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Prince:

I don’t think continuous wrap would work for us because we can’t go above 360

But your position reading is going over 1 rotation (360-degrees), back to your original post. It all depends what you’re trying to do, and how you’re trying to do it.

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: Do u think modulus is necessary if we use sync and continuous wrap? Also does continuous wrap every make the end effector go back a full rotation at any point?

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: is the discontinuity point based on the adjusted value(after offset) or raw value?

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
The discontinuity point is meant to be a position after applying offsets, sensor direction, etc. The discontinuity point is where absolute position at boot wraps from x-1 to x (or vice versa).

If you have a hard stop preventing you from going a full 360, then find the position reported at both extremes of the hard stop (all the way back and all the way forward). As an example, if those give values of 0.7 and -0.2 (which is the same as 0.8), then your discontinuity point would be around 0.75 rot.

If those give practically the same position, then consider which position is more likely to be your boot position. If the -0.2 case is more likely, for example, maybe you move the discontinuity point down a bit to 0.7 rot. On the other hand, if the 0.7 rot case is mroe likely, then maybe move it up a bit to 0.8 rot.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.custom_user_title: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.name: Marc Pulte
posts.cooked:
I’d expect the fused or sync feedback sensor source to work better for you. We’re using a fused CANdi with a REV through bore sensor without problems, but our offset and range is a bit different from yours. You can compare to our configuration if you like.

If the issue is indeed that the offset + initial position is adding up to over 1 and fused/sync feedback doesn’t mitigate it for you, there may be a couple of options.

You could try reseting the motor position to an equivalent value within the [0-1) range. That’s where modulus could be of use. motor.setPosition(currentPosition % 1) . I’d recommend doing this in a way that it won’t be requested every loop, such as only if the position is outside the [0-1) range.

You could send position requests in the [1 - 2) range when your sensor value is in that range. Integer division of the position signal is your friend here. I.E. output = demand + (int)currentPosition . Limits on your motor position would need to be adjusted to account for this, making it overall less safe.

Reseat your sensor so that your offset can’t result in this case.

Of course, this logic would need to change a bit if your discontinuity point were any value other than 1.

I definitely wouldn’t recommend continuous mode since that would always try to take the smallest turn between any two angles. It’s more meant for applications such as swerve azimuth.

Just to confirm, is your discontinuity point 1 because your expected range of motion is something like 0.1 - 0.9? You want the discontinuity point to be outside the range of motion.
